subject: Productivity
title: Anders Ericsson and Deliberate Practice
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Anders Ericsson and Deliberate Practice.

hook.text: The 10,000 hour rule is wrong. Ericsson, the scientist behind it, said quality of practice matters more.

buildup.text: Anders Ericsson studied elite violinists, chess players, and athletes. All used deliberate practice.

discovery.text: Deliberate practice targets weaknesses with focused effort and immediate feedback. It's uncomfortable by design.

twist.text: Top performers practiced only 3-4 hours of deliberate work per day. More than that led to diminishing returns.

climax.text: Ericsson proved that excellence comes from how you practice, not how long. Mindless repetition builds nothing.

punchline.text: Practice doesn't make perfect. Deliberate practice does.

quiz.question: How many hours of deliberate practice did top performers average daily?
